title: Red Rock Fury
text:
Perched in the desert, proud and absurd,
A sandstone cliff — an Angry Bird.
Its beak juts sharp, its brow is stern,
As if it’s awaiting its turn to burn.
The wind plays slingshot, the clouds take aim,
But this rock just chuckles, immune to the game.
Forever frozen in feathery guise,
A grumpy guardian under bluebird skies.
Lizards parade by its scowling face,
Whispering tales of this lofty place.
Tourists snap photos, delighted to find,
A relic of pixels in stone redefined.
And when twilight paints the canyon red,
The Angry Bird will live on in your head.
A game once played on a glowing screen,
Now etched by time in a desert scene.

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





Somewhere on the D4 trail, you’ll find a rock that looks like a bird from the angry birds video game.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?








This feature is located in the loop section of the D4 trail. It can be found somewhere in the area highlighted in purple above. Click for an interactive map.











TipHint #3: Ok, I need a photo hint please.

title: Guardian of the Flume
text:
If you wander where the waters run,
Past sandstone cliffs in desert sun,
You’ll find a beast both strange and sly,
With wooden jaws that snap the sky.
Its tail is curled beneath itself,
A driftwood gator perched on the shelf.
Or maybe some old canyon sprite,
Who guards the Inner Flume day and night.
Hikers stop with wide-eyed cheer:
“Look! A dragon’s waiting here!”
Carved by flood and nature’s play,
Its roar scares only the dust away.
So if you roam above the Flume’s embrace,
And stumble on this creature’s place,
Just wave and laugh, don’t be afraid —
The canyon’s myths are all homemade!

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





Somewhere on the F1 trail, you can look across Inner Flume and see a creature tucked into the canyon wall.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?








This feature is visible from the F1 trail. It can be found somewhere in the area highlighted in purple above. Click for an interactive map.

title: The Dapper Duck of Fruita
text:
Near Fruita stands a rock so odd,
A sandstone duck that gives a nod.
With fancy hat perched on its head,
It looks like royalty instead!
This stony fowl with fashion sense
Makes tourists stop in pure suspense.
“Is that a duck wearing a hat?”
“Or am I stoned?” (It might be that!)
The Colorado winds may blow,
But duckie’s hat won’t ever go.
While other ducks must swim and fly,
This one just winks at passers-by.

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





Somewhere on the D4 trail, you’ll find a rock shaped like a duck wearing a hat.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?

title: Sandstone Sonnets
text:
Welcome! We’re so glad you’re here.
On this page you’ll find poems written about natural features in and around Fruita, Colorado. These are a bit like a scavenger hunt - see if you can figure out what features these poems describe.

On this page you’ll find poems written about natural features in and around Fruita, Colorado. These are a bit like a scavenger hunt - see if you can figure out what features these poems describe.

title: Sandstone Sonnets

Trailhead filters

Flume Canyon

title: FAQ
text:
How do I use this website?
Use the “Trailhead filters” section on the homepage to find a trail near you. Select a trail to explore.
The “Poems” section will now be filtered to just the trail selected.
Features on out-and-back trails are numbered sequentially, in the order they are found on the hike in. Features on loop trails are numbered in a clockwise fashion. If you’re hiking counter-clockwise, you’ll see them in reverse order.
Each poem will give you clues about what shape to look for in the rocks. If you’re stuck, there are hints at the bottom of the page under each poem. Clicking the hint will expand it.
Once you think you’ve found the rock formation described in the poem, click the “Answer” tab. It will show you a picture of the formation and a map showing the location where the picture was taken.


I hate to tell you this, but these aren’t sonnets.
I hate to tell you this, but that isn’t a question. Nonetheless, your point is a good one – these aren’t sonnets. We liked the alliteration of Sandstone Sonnets more than we liked actual sonnets.


I think the rocks look like something different. How can I let you know?
Email us! We love hearing from readers. If you have a suggestion for a different shape or interpretation, please let us know!


Can I submit a poem to Sandstone Sonnets?
For sure! Send us an email! Please include the trailhead and trail section you are writing about, as well as any hints you think would be helpful. We reserve the right to edit submissions for clarity, but you will receive credit for your poem.

title: The Canyon’s Secret Grin
text:
If you search the canyon wall,
A cheeky smile grins down at all.
Red rock carved by wind and time,
Sharing nature’s favorite rhyme.
Green trees giggle from above,
Junipers whisper tales of love.
While hikers stop and point with glee:
“Look! The canyon’s smiling at me!”
This sandstone jester never frowns,
Just grins at all the desert towns.
A million-year-old happy face,
That makes D4 such a lovely place!
So if you’re walking Fruita’s trails
And need a laugh when courage fails,
Just look up at that crimson wall,
The canyon’s smiling after all!

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





There is a place somewhere on the D4 trail where it looks as though a big smile was carved into the sandstone.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?








This feature is located in the loop section of the D4 trail. It can be found somewhere in the area highlighted in purple above. Click for an interactive map.











TipHint #3: Ok, I need a photo hint please.

Smile!

title: The Desert Shipwreck
text:
If you venture where the cliffs stand high,
A breaching whale will catch your eye.
Its sandstone flukes once crashed the sea,
And wrecked a ship for all to see.
The vessel lingered, ghostly drawn,
Its sails were torn, its crew long gone.
Yet its ghostly shell still remains,
A sandstone hull upon the plain.
The whale looks proud, a trickster bold,
A million years of tales retold.
While desert winds still sing a song:
The whale’s been laughing all along.
So if you stroll these rugged lands,
With dust and wonder in your hands,
Look close, the tale is clear:
A whale sunk that ship right here!

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





You are searching for two large rocks. One of them looks like a whale breaching out of the water. Behind it, you’ll find another rock that looks like a sinking ship.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?








This feature is visible from the F1 trail. It can be found somewhere in the area highlighted in purple above. Click for an interactive map.











TipHint #3: Ok, I need a photo hint please.








Here’s a blurred version of the location you’re looking for. See anything that looks like this?














GPS coordinates of this photo: NEED TO CONFIRM 39.151625, -108.781861

title: Patina Portrait
text:
Look across the canyon face,
A weathered man holds his place.
With hair of brown and moustache too,
A coat of varnish, earthen hue.
No brush has touched this rocky wall,
Yet nature’s paint outshines them all.
An Old West portrait formed in desert glaze,
Was he a sheriff? Merchant? Who’s to say?
His eyes are gone, worn smooth by time,
Yet still he keeps a watch sublime.
Flume canyon rests beneath his gaze,
An old prospector from those bygone days?
So give a nod as you pass on by,
This stoic stranger won’t reply.
But desert varnish keeps him near,
A patinaed figure from yesteryear.

HintsAnswer


Click to expand the sections below.






TipHint #1: Help…what am I looking for?





Somewhere on the F1 trail, there is varnish on the sandstone that looks a little like a portrait of someone from the Old West.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?
